title: 2013 Copa Sudamericana
text:
The 2013 Copa Sudamericana (officially the 2013 Copa <a href="Total%20S.A.">Total</a> Sudamericana for sponsorship reasons) was the 12th edition of the <a href="Copa%20Sudamericana">Copa Sudamericana</a>, <a href="South%20America">South America</a>'s secondary international club <a href="association%20football">football</a> tournament organized by <a href="CONMEBOL">CONMEBOL</a>. The winner qualified for the <a href="2014%20Copa%20Libertadores">2014 Copa Libertadores</a>, the <a href="2014%20Recopa%20Sudamericana">2014 Recopa Sudamericana</a>, and the <a href="2014%20Suruga%20Bank%20Championship">2014 Suruga Bank Championship</a>. <a href="S%C3%A3o%20Paulo%20FC">São Paulo</a> were the defending champions, but lost to <a href="Associa%C3%A7%C3%A3o%20Atl%C3%A9tica%20Ponte%20Preta">Ponte Preta</a> in the semifinals.
<a href="Club%20Atl%C3%A9tico%20Lan%C3%BAs">Lanús</a> became the fifth Argentine club to win the Copa Sudamericana, beating Brazilian club <a href="Associa%C3%A7%C3%A3o%20Atl%C3%A9tica%20Ponte%20Preta">Ponte Preta</a> in the <a href="2013%20Copa%20Sudamericana%20Finals">finals</a> to win their first title.

Draw.
The draw of the tournament was held on July 3, 2013 in <a href="Buenos%20Aires">Buenos Aires</a>, <a href="Argentina">Argentina</a>.

To determine the bracket starting from the round of 16, the defending champion and the 15 winners of the second stage were assigned a "seed" by draw. The defending champion and the winners from Argentina Zone and Brazil Zone were assigned even-numbered "seeds", and the winners from ties between South Zone and North Zone were assigned odd-numbered "seeds".
Schedule.
The schedule of the competition was as follows (all dates listed were Wednesdays, but matches may be played on Tuesdays and Thursdays as well).
Elimination phase.
In the elimination phase, each tie was played on a home-and-away <a href="two-legged%20tie">two-legged</a> basis. If tied on aggregate, the <a href="away%20goals%20rule">away goals rule</a> was used. If still tied, the <a href="penalty%20shoot-out%20%28association%20football%29">penalty shoot-out</a> was used to determine the winner (no <a href="extra%20time%20%28association%20football%29">extra time</a> is played). The 15 winners of the second stage (three from Argentina Zone, four from Brazil Zone, eight from ties between South Zone and North Zone) advanced to the <a href="%23Final%20stages">round of 16</a> to join the defending champion (<a href="S%C3%A3o%20Paulo%20FC">São Paulo</a>).

Final stages.
In the final stages, the 16 teams played a <a href="single-elimination%20tournament">single-elimination tournament</a>, with the following rules:
Bracket.
Note: The bracket was changed according to the rules of the tournament so that the two semifinalists from Brazil would play each other.
Finals.
The finals were played on a home-and-away <a href="two-legged%20tie">two-legged</a> basis, with the higher-seeded team hosting the second leg. If tied on aggregate, the <a href="away%20goals%20rule">away goals rule</a> was not used, and 30 minutes of <a href="extra%20time%20%28association%20football%29">extra time</a> was played. If still tied after extra time, the <a href="penalty%20shoot-out%20%28association%20football%29">penalty shoot-out</a> was used to determine the winner.
